content.description: Baseball statisticians studied how often triples (a certain event in a baseball game) occurred in professional games played between 1947 and 2017. A 98 percent confidence interval to estimate the slope of the linear regression line relating the year, <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and the mean number of triples per game, <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, yielded <math alttext="negative 0.006 comma negative 0.002" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>0.006</mn></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow><mrow><mn>0.002</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>. A check shows that the conditions necessary for inference for the slope of the regression line are met.
content.question: Based on the confidence interval, which of the following claims is supported?

choices.label: The mean number of triples per game is between 0.002 and 0.006.
The number of triples per game has increased, on average, per year.
There is no linear relationship between the mean number of triples per game and year.
There is a negative linear relationship between the mean number of triples per game and year.
A conclusion cannot be made about the relationship between year and mean number of triples per game because the values are close to 0.

content.answer: There is a negative linear relationship between the mean number of triples per game and year.
